image.altText: Trump in front of a US flag, raising his fist

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump is indicted on criminal charges. Follow live.

title.children: Trump indicted by grand jury on four charges over 2020 election

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Taking to social media, the former vice-president said the indictment "serves as an important reminder [that] anyone who puts himself over the Constitution should never be president fo the United States". Pence: I will have more to say about the government’s case after reviewing the indictment. The former president is entitled to the presumption of innocence but with this indictment, his candidacy means more talk about January 6th and more distractions. Our country is more important than one man. Our constitution is more important than any one man’s career. On January 6th, Former President Trump demanded that I choose between him and the Constitution. I chose the Constitution and I always will.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mike Pence: 'Our country is more important than one man'

children.content: Taking to social media, the former vice-president said the indictment "serves as an important reminder [that] anyone who puts himself over the Constitution should never be president fo the United States".
Pence:
I will have more to say about the government’s case after reviewing the indictment.
The former president is entitled to the presumption of innocence but with this indictment, his candidacy means more talk about January 6th and more distractions.
Our country is more important than one man. Our constitution is more important than any one man’s career.
On January 6th, Former President Trump demanded that I choose between him and the Constitution. I chose the Constitution and I always will.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan has more: Jade: There’s a familiar pattern to the way Donald Trump has responded to the three criminal cases brought against him. The former president once again broke the news of his impending indictment himself on his social media platform, Truth Social. He followed up that post with a statement accusing federal prosecutors of trying to interfere in next year’s presidential race, in which he’s still considered the leading candidate for the Republican nomination. And just like in the other two cases, his team immediately started appealing to supporters for donations. “What better way to show that YOU stood by the President’s side through *EVERY* phony indictment than your very own Limited-Edition “I STAND WITH TRUMP” T-Shirt, ” an email read. Donald Trump’s campaign says he’s raised millions of dollars since he was indicted in New York earlier this year, but reports suggest his legal fees have also put major pressure on his political action committee. Those costs will continue to mount, with the former president already facing the prospect of two criminal trials next year, and Jack Smith now pushing for a “speedy” resolution to the third.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Despite facing three criminal cases, Trump is still considered the leading Republican candidate

children.content: The ABC's North America bureau chief
Jade Macmillan
has more:
Jade:
There’s a familiar pattern to the way Donald Trump has responded to the three criminal cases brought against him.
The former president once again broke the news of his impending indictment himself on his social media platform, Truth Social.

He followed up that post with a statement accusing federal prosecutors of trying to interfere in next year’s presidential race, in which he’s still considered the leading candidate for the Republican nomination.
And just like in the other two cases, his team immediately started appealing to supporters for donations.
“What better way to show that YOU stood by the President’s side through *EVERY* phony indictment than your very own Limited-Edition “I STAND WITH TRUMP” T-Shirt,
” an email read.

Donald Trump’s campaign says he’s raised millions of dollars since he was indicted in New York earlier this year, but reports suggest his legal fees have also put major pressure on his political action committee.
Those costs will continue to mount, with the former president already facing the prospect of two criminal trials next year, and Jack Smith now pushing for a “speedy” resolution to the third.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Responding to this morning's indictment, Merrick Garland says immediately after the January 6 attack, "the career men and women of the Justice Department engaged in what has become the largest investigation in our history". "[Jack] Smith and his team of experienced, principled, career agents and prosecutors have followed the facts and the law wherever they lead," he said. "Any questions about this matter will have to be answered by the filings made in a courtroom."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US Attorney-General: Capitol riot has been 'the largest investigation in our history'

children.content: Responding to this morning's indictment,
Merrick Garland
says immediately after the January 6 attack, "the career men and women of the Justice Department engaged in what has become the largest investigation in our history".
"[Jack] Smith and his team of experienced, principled, career agents and prosecutors have followed the facts and the law wherever they lead," he said.
"Any questions about this matter will have to be answered by the filings made in a courtroom."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Poland's government says two Belarusian helicopters entered its airspace this morning — an incident which comes amid rising tensions along the NATO member's border with the Russian ally. Warsaw authorities say they will increase Poland's military presence along the border in response, and have summoned Belarus' top diplomat in Warsaw in protest. In a statement, Poland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs says it "communicated its firm opposition and called the Belarusian side to immediately explain the incident". "The Polish side underlined that the incident is considered as another element in escalating the tension at the Polish-Belarusian border," it says. "Poland expects Belarus to refrain from this type of activity." Anxieties have grown in Poland and in neighbouring Lithuania after mercenaries from the Russia-linked Wagner group arrived in Belarus following their short-lived rebellion against the Kremlin in June. You can read more background here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Poland says two Belarusian helicopters have violated its airspace

featuredLink.title: Poland sends troops to Belarus border fearing airspace violations

children.content: Poland's government says two Belarusian helicopters entered its airspace this morning — an incident which comes amid rising tensions along the NATO member's border with the Russian ally.
Warsaw authorities say
they will increase Poland's military presence along the border in response
, and have summoned Belarus' top diplomat in Warsaw in protest.
In a statement, Poland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs says it "communicated its firm opposition and called the Belarusian side to immediately explain the incident".
"The Polish side underlined that the incident is considered as another element in escalating the tension at the Polish-Belarusian border," it says.
"Poland expects Belarus to refrain from this type of activity."

Anxieties have grown in Poland and in neighbouring Lithuania after mercenaries from the Russia-linked Wagner group arrived in Belarus following their short-lived rebellion against the Kremlin in June.
You can read more background here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The family of Henrietta Lacks has reached a settlement with the US biotech firm which used her cancer cells to develop revolutionary new treatments after her death in 1951. Tissue taken from Lacks's cervical cancer tumor without her consent became the first human cells to continuously grow and reproduce in lab dishes. The cells were then used without her family's full knowledge until a book about the story was published in 2010. So-called HeLa cells went on to become a cornerstone of modern medicine, enabling countless scientific and medical innovations, including the development of the polio vaccine, genetic mapping and even COVID-19 vaccines. In their complaint, Lacks's descendants argue that her treatment illustrates a much larger issue that persists today: racism inside the US medical system. "The exploitation of Henrietta Lacks represents the unfortunately common struggle experienced by Black people throughout history," the complaint reads.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Henrietta Lacks’s family reach a settlement with a company that used her cells without consent

props.alt: A close up of a black-and-white photo of a woman, in a wooden frame.

children.content: (Getty Images: Jonathan Newton/The Washington Post)
The family of Henrietta Lacks has reached a settlement with the US biotech firm which used her cancer cells to develop revolutionary new treatments after her death in 1951.
Tissue taken from Lacks's cervical cancer tumor without her consent became the first human cells to continuously grow and reproduce in lab dishes
The cells were then used without her family's full knowledge until a book about the story was published in 2010.

So-called HeLa cells went on to become a cornerstone of modern medicine, enabling countless scientific and medical innovations, including the development of the polio vaccine, genetic mapping and even COVID-19 vaccines.
In their complaint, Lacks's descendants argue that her treatment illustrates a much larger issue that persists today: racism inside the US medical system.
"The exploitation of Henrietta Lacks represents the unfortunately common struggle experienced by Black people throughout history," the complaint reads.

props.alt: A group of people walking on a footpath outside of a courthouse in the United States.

children.content: (AP: Steve Ruark)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A plan to raise more money by taxing big gas and oil companies faces an uphill battle as independent senator David Pocock reveals he is willing to vote against the proposal as it stands. The ACT senator says a proposed petroleum resource rent tax is a "disappointing" and "weak" approach from the Albanese government and is calling for it to be higher. "I would much rather see the rate of PRRT raised from 40 per cent up to 50 or 60 per cent, which is what a bunch of experts are saying should happen," Pocock tells ABC Radio. "We've got to actually look at getting a fair return for our resources (because) these gas companies are making record, wartime profits selling our gas back to us at international prices and they're not even paying the PRRT which is this royalty." Senator Pocock says without major changes from the government, he will vote down the proposal. "I can't cop them telling Australians who are who are doing it tough that 'I'm sorry, the budget is tight'," he says. You can hear the full interview here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: David Pocock say he'll vote down a 'weak' tax on gas and oil companies

featuredLink.title: David Pocock: 'I'm prepared to vote it down' - ABC Radio National

props.alt: A bald man stand and speaking, gesturing with his hands

children.content: (ABC: Australian Story/Matt Roberts)
A plan to raise more money by taxing big gas and oil companies faces an uphill battle as independent senator David Pocock reveals he is willing to vote against the proposal as it stands.
The ACT senator
says a proposed petroleum resource rent tax is a "disappointing" and "weak" approach
from the Albanese government and is calling for it to be higher.
"I would much rather see the rate of PRRT raised from 40 per cent up to 50 or 60 per cent, which is what a bunch of experts are saying should happen," Pocock tells ABC Radio.

"We've got to actually look at getting a fair return for our resources (because) these gas companies are making record, wartime profits selling our gas back to us at international prices and they're not even paying the PRRT which is this royalty."
Senator Pocock says without major changes from the government, he will vote down the proposal.
"I can't cop them telling Australians who are who are doing it tough that 'I'm sorry, the budget is tight'," he says.
You can hear the full interview here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ride share firm Uber has swung from loss to profit for the second quarter of the financial year. Uber made a net profit of $US394 million ($596) from a net loss of $US2.6 billion ($3.9 billion) from the same quarter last year. Profit was boosted as it share market investments were revalued higher. Gross bookings rose by 16 per cent over the year to $US33.6 billion. Uber chief executive Dana Khosrwoshahi said the company saw its first quarterly operating profit and its first quarter of free cash flow of more than $US1 billion. However, its shares fell 5.7 per cent because its revenue of $US9.2 billion wasn't as good as expected by analysts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Uber makes second quarter profit

children.content: Ride share firm Uber has swung from loss to profit for the second quarter of the financial year.
Uber made a net profit of $US394 million ($596) from a net loss of $US2.6 billion ($3.9 billion) from the same quarter last year.
Profit was boosted as it share market investments were revalued higher.
Gross bookings rose by 16 per cent over the year to $US33.6 billion.
Uber chief executive Dana Khosrwoshahi said the company saw its first quarterly operating profit and its first quarter of free cash flow of more than $US1 billion.
However, its shares fell 5.7 per cent because its revenue of $US9.2 billion wasn't as good as expected by analysts.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has lost ground in early trade, after yesterday's strong showing on the back of the Reserve Bank keeping interest rates on hold. The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent in early trade tracking global markets lower after manufacturing contracted around the world, including in China. Most sectors are in the red led down by real estate, utilities, banks and miners. The top movers are: Sayona Mining: +1.6% Resmed: +1.4% Reliance Worldwide: +1.3% AGL Energy: -3.8% EVT: - 3.4% Champion Iron: -3.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower

children.content: The Australian share market has lost ground in early trade, after yesterday's strong showing on the back of the Reserve Bank keeping interest rates on hold.
The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent in early trade tracking global markets lower after manufacturing contracted around the world, including in China.
Most sectors are in the red led down by real estate, utilities, banks and miners.
The top movers are:
Sayona Mining: +1.6%
Resmed: +1.4%
Reliance Worldwide: +1.3%
AGL Energy: -3.8%
Champion Iron: -3.1%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After the Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold yesterday at 4.1 per cent, more economists think this may be the end of the RBA's rate-hiking cycle. RBA governor Philip Lowe noted that higher interest rates were bringing down inflation, but did not rule out raising borrowing costs again with annual inflation running at 6 per cent. Barrenjoey chief economist Jo Masters has lowered her forecasts for where official rates will peak, from 4.6 per cent to 4.1 per cent. She says it is likely the RBA board thinks there have been enough interest rate rises to lower inflation to between 2 to 3 per cent by mid-2025. "We read today’s statement as a signal that the board believes there is sufficient  tightening in the pipeline to achieve their inflation objective; that they want to be done  with the tightening cycle. "This sets a high bar to further rate hikes, and the onus on  the data to surprise sufficiently to force the board’s hand back to the table." UBS chief economist George Tharenou has lowered his forecast for the terminal rate from 4.35 per cent to 4.1 per cent, although a 0.25 per cent rise in November is possible, before a cut mid next year. The Commonwealth Bank now also expects the cash rate to remain on hold at 4.1 per cent for an extended period. National Australia Bank expects the peak cash rate to reach 4.35 per cent in November. Interest rate rises are slowing the economy with weaker inflation and retail sales. The recovery in home prices is also easing. Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers on The Business.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the RBA stop raising rates now?

featuredLink.title: How interest rates are impacting house prices

children.content: After the Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold yesterday at 4.1 per cent, more economists think this may be the end of the RBA's rate-hiking cycle.
RBA governor Philip Lowe noted that higher interest rates were bringing down inflation, but did not rule out raising borrowing costs again with annual inflation running at 6 per cent.
Barrenjoey chief economist Jo Masters
has lowered her forecasts for where official rates will peak, from 4.6 per cent to 4.1 per cent.
She says it is likely the RBA board thinks there have been enough interest rate rises to lower inflation to between 2 to 3 per cent by mid-2025.

"We read today’s statement as a signal that the board believes there is sufficient  tightening in the pipeline to achieve their inflation objective; that they want to be done  with the tightening cycle.
"This sets a high bar to further rate hikes, and the onus on  the data to surprise sufficiently to force the board’s hand back to the table."
UBS chief economist George Tharenou
has lowered his forecast for the terminal rate from 4.35 per cent to 4.1 per cent, although a 0.25 per cent rise in November is possible, before a cut mid next year.
The Commonwealth Bank now also expects the cash rate to remain on hold at 4.1 per cent for an extended period.
National Australia Bank expects the peak cash rate to reach 4.35 per cent in November.
Interest rate rises are slowing the economy with weaker inflation and retail sales.
The recovery in home prices is also easing.
Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers on The Business.
